body:
```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```
Note that this is only safe because we know that the grpclb code and the callback are both running in the same combiner.  It might be good to add a comment to that effect.

Looks like the original closure will run on [client channel filter's combiner](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc#L1375) (which is also the combiner of the LB policies) while the wrapper one will run on [`exec_ctx_scheduler`](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1560)? 

This wrapper is the only closure in this file that runs on `exec_ctx_scheduler`. Should it actually run on the client channel filter's (also the LB policy's) combiner?
I just pushed a new commit. Please take a look at the update. Thanks! @markdroth

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/fd7683c7de14fd93f9696e3aee8abf51d64745b3/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc#L2636

There are places where the closure is not scheduled on the same combiner but on the exec_ctx_scheduler instead.

@yashykt, that code-path just re-uses the `pick_closure` field to exit the combiner; it does not get passed into the LB policy for a pick.  I do not believe that there are any cases where the pick completion closure will not run on the client_channel combiner.

@yashykt We are re-using that closure to do different things. For the one where we pass it into the LB policies (and then wrap it), it's always inited with the combiner.

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/fd7683c7de14fd93f9696e3aee8abf51d64745b3/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc#L2672
Since from previous comments it does look like a correctness issue, I am fine with getting this done first, but it might be worth auditing the rest of the closure scheduling sometime in the future :)

Does this mean we want to convert these too?

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1114

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1139

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1164

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1200

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1614

https://github.com/AspirinSJL/grpc/blob/2393c98ec9b10edc45850442671cda6f5f076d80/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L1633
From a quick glance at all of those other call sites, I suspect they're all fine to change as well.

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```

I have looked at all the `GRPC_CLOSURE_SCHED` under client channel folder, and changed them to `GRPC_CLOSURE_RUN` if the caller and callee are both run in the client channel combiner or both run by `exec_ctx_scheduler`.

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```
Well, apparently there is some wrong change. I will check tomorrow.


If we can only RUN closures on exec_ctx_scheduler at the end of the callback, why don't we do this in the combiner scheduler case? Are we guaranteed that the closures run on combiner are not holding locks other than the combiner?

I'm guessing what Mark's saying is that if we do decide to use GRPC_CLOSURE_RUN for exec_ctx_scheduler, let's do it in a more uniform way. I think @kpayson64 had tried to switch all GRPC_CLOSURE_SCHED to GRPC_CLOSURE_RUN but he was getting all sorts of errors.

You are right in that combiner has the same limitations about locks. I would honestly be fine if you are willing to do it but it would be much more painful

There is no *guarantee* that closures running in the smae combiner hold no other locks, but (a) the combiner itself is a lock, so it seems unlikely that the closures would need some other lock, and (b) the very fact that they're all running in the same combiner means that we are already in a mode where we are having to coordinate their activity, so having to do some additional thought to ensure that there are no other deadlocks doesn't seem like a big deal.  The same cannot be said of an arbitrary pair of closures running on the exec_ctx scheduler, which is why I think we need to think more carefully about that change.  And as Yash said, if we're going to make that change, we should do it everywhere, not just in the client_channel code.
I see. Thanks for explaining @yashykt @markdroth! That sounds reasonable to me.
